description:
Languages are at the same time very different from one another and yet
also very similar. How is that possible? To answer this question, we need to
think of language not only as a set of words and their associated sounds,
but also as a more abstract object: a set of mental principles that govern
how we put together the various components of a complex grammatical
system. This course explores the general principles that underlie how we
combine words to form sentences, focusing on similarities and differences
across languages.
title: The Structure of Language
